captions.text: [INTRO MUSIC]

In these troubled times, with neofascism nipping 
at our toes and climate disaster

ruffling our hair like an obnoxious
relative at a wedding, little wonder that we turn so

often to nostalgia. It&#39;s like a big,
warm, comforting family dog sitting in the corner

continually eating its own sick. How
fitting that so soon after the community requested

I review Chrono Trigger that an indie
game very heavily inspired by it should come out.

Sea of Stars developed by Sabotage, the
lads who made The Messenger, a retro-inspired action

platformer that I thought was rather
good if a touch overwritten. Probably for the best

that they moved to classic JRPGs, I
suppose, ain&#39;t no one complaining when those are a

touch overwritten. If anything people
complain if you get to the end and God doesn&#39;t mouth off

the 300 lines about the futility of our
struggle and how he certainly isn&#39;t about to have his
papal orbs handed to him by the power of

friendship. Also, The
Escapist put out a documentary on Sea

of Stars development recently so I figured
I&#39;d better give it a look to make sure it&#39;s not a

load of old dog sick or we&#39;re all gonna
have half-digested bonio on our faces. Sea of Stars

tells the story of two youngsters whose
names despite the many hours we spent together I&#39;m
now going to have to google to remember. Zale and

Valere. There we go.
Valere? Why not Valery? Did you

get traumatised by a letter I on the set of
Sesame Street or something? Anyway, one of them has the

power of the sun and one of them has the power
of the moon and they&#39;re trained almost from birth to

be the new generation of solstice warriors at
a weirdly specific academy that&#39;s weirdly close to

where they live. On the eve of their
graduation it was already becoming clear that there was

something fishy going on behind all this.
Why does the academy have only two students in about
sixteen empty beds? Why do the two solstice

warriors from the previous
generation keep pointing to the

headmaster behind his back and making
weird throat cutting gestures? And then there&#39;s the

matter of Zale and Valere&#39;s childhood
friend, Garl. There&#39;s a flashback where they get into

trouble in a dungeon together as kids and
Garl loses an eye and that&#39;s the last they see of him

before getting sealed
away in the academy and he&#39;s

mysteriously absent
from their graduation 10 years

later. And by this point there&#39;d been an
ominous cutaway scene depicting several scheming villains

wearing masks, so I figured I knew where this
was going. Oh, they&#39;re gonna knock one of the masks

off and it&#39;s Garl wearing an eye patch and
he&#39;s all bitter at being abandoned by his friends,

sword fighting the rain, lots of yelling,
last episode of Cowboy Bebop, etc etc. That&#39;s what I

thought. But then two minutes later Garl
just shows up. &quot;Hey guys, hope you had a nice decade,

can I be your third party member? I
made sandwiches.&quot; And then he just is. So I was a

bit thrown but over time I came to
appreciate Garle because at this point Zale and Valere are

basically weirdo monks who spent their
formative years locked away from society learning how to

atomize monsters by doing sign language at
them. And Garl is the only party member with actual

personality and social skills. And it becomes
a running joke how often he makes friends with the

boss fights after we&#39;ve duffed them up
enough. He&#39;s like that one infuriating D&amp;D player who&#39;s

like an 18 charisma paladin and insists
on trying to talk down every combat encounter,

so the DM ends up having to keep track
of 16 helper NPCs and is seriously considering

committing murder suicide using the dice
bag as an improvised flail. So the three of you set

off on your standard quest to defeat evil
god, but while I thought Chrono Trigger&#39;s plot suffered

from losing the personal touch once the
whole evil god business hoped into view, like a zeppelin

at a plate spinning contest, Sea of Stars
keeps the focus on the dynamic of the three leads for

the most part, although a lot of the
additional NPCs have a bad case of &quot;the authors seem to think

this character is cool stroke funny stroke
interesting but aren&#39;t conveying that very well&quot;

like the three severely over-designed pirates
who show up now and then to do sod all. And there&#39;s

this ninja pirate who just sort of elbows her
way into the party at one point, probably with some

complex backstory or other, but frankly
they weren&#39;t interesting enough to make me give much

of a toss. Also, ninja pirate? What is this,
early 2000s web humour? As for the plot, once it gets

going it falls back a little too often on the
old &quot;prove your worth to the gods destined warriors&quot;

chestnut where we go from one ancient dungeon
to another to get the magical macguffin that opens

the next one. Don&#39;t see why we couldn&#39;t
ask for a cocking certificate after the first time,

like it&#39;s a costco membership, but nope,
just gotta keep proving our worth like we&#39;re on The

Bachelor or something. Still, the gameplay&#39;s
solid. Well, the primary gameplay&#39;s solid. There&#39;s a

fishing minigame, I assume in accordance
with the doctrine from the indie games United Nations,

and it&#39;s probably the most vestigial
fishing minigame I&#39;ve ever encountered, and that&#39;s like

being the most derivative true crime
YouTube channel. But the combat successfully finds ways

to spice up the turn-based battling
without making it not turn-based anymore, which was the

sticking point in Chrono Trigger&#39;s active
time battle approach for me. It&#39;s got the now fairly

standard issue Mario RPG-style timed hits,
but there&#39;s also a rather neat little idea where you

can parry certain enemy attacks by hitting
them with a random sequence of specific kinds of damage.

It avoids fights turning into endless
repeating slogs of attack, heal, attack, heal, and requires

a bit of strategising on the fly, and it&#39;s
very satisfying when the boss has to lose a turn and

just sit there impotently mouthing
objections because you successfully coordinated three frying

pan hits and a knee in
the bollocks, but if I were
to mark the main strike against the gameplay with

my big chunky permanent marker, it&#39;s
possible that it tries a little too hard to be accessible,

which may only be a problem if you&#39;re one of
those genetic lottery winners who throw their copy of

Atlas Shrugged out of the pram whenever
anyone brings up adding easy mode to Dark Souls, but I

never felt particularly challenged. The game
might be a touch too generous with letting us run back

to the campfire to full party heal between
every combat. Probably why we&#39;re only allowed 10 healing

items lest we break the difficulty further
with an inexhaustible horde of steak sandwiches sitting

there in our inventory leaking juice all over
the settings menu. There&#39;s even a bunch of equipable

relics that act as optional easy modes
Final Fantasy XVI style, like one that automatically

does the timed hits for ya, or one that
reduces damage, which brought on a philosophical moment.

Reduce damage? That&#39;s just armour, isn&#39;t
it? Is using armour playing the game on easy mode?

Whence lies the border between using the
standard tools the game gives you and using the baby mode

workaround for crap outs? Well I know what
Ayn Rand would say if she were alive. She&#39;d say,
&quot;Why am I in this coffin? It&#39;s very dark.&quot;
